./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Purpose of this demonstration
This book chapter is to demonstrate the feasibility of using GitBook for course content delivery. The book was firstly developed in GitBook editor, and then is hosted through Github. We expect to have a simple, concise, free, and easily maintained platform, which can be accessed by anyone who are interested in to deliver a course for either flipped learning or on-line teaching.  For example, during flipped learning, teachers can deliver course contents in this way. Then student can access them before the class room. Compared with current on-line education platforms, such as Udacity or Coursera, users don not need support from IT professional. For simplicity, this platform does not intend to for course management such as grading, submission, or attendance checking.  We want to keep both the interface and the function as simple as possible. More generally, this platform can be viewed as a platform to deliver interactive multimedia text book.
For this purpose, we developed the first week course content of introduction to signal processing. Several third party plugins has been tested and installed to enable video, equations, quiz, and code snippet. Through this project, we want reach a conclusion if GitBook similar platform is good for course content delivery? What are current limitations for current GitBook platform? Could we develop a similar platform but can serve users better?

chapter1.html.title: Week1. Signal and Conversion
chapter1.html.body:
Learning Objectives

Explain the concepts of analog and digital signal
Understand the process of converting analog signal to digital signal
Be able to explain time sampling
Be able to explain quantization and understand the source of error during quantization
Understand how digital signal is saved in computer
Can covert a decimal integer number to a binary number
Understand the format of floating number**

chapter1/signal-and-system.html.title: Analog and Digital Signals
chapter1/signal-and-system.html.body:
In this section, you need to understand what analog and digital singals are and why we need to covert them.






  
  
    To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that
    supports HTML5 video
  






Simulation of analog signal with time sampling
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
# Generate a continue signal 
t = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi,1000)
plt.plot(t,np.cos(t))

# returns 10 evenly spaced samples from 0.1 to 2*PI
t_sample = np.linspace(0.1, 2 * np.pi, 10)
markerline, stemlines, baseline = plt.stem(t_sample, np.cos(t_sample), '-.')

# setting property of baseline with color red and linewidth 2
plt.setp(baseline, color='r', linewidth=2)

chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization..title: Signal Conversion: Quantization
chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization..body:
After sampling analog signal in time domain, we just complete the first step. In order for computer processing, the sampled values must be converted into binary numbers. In this section, we are going to first introduce binary number then introduce the errors induced during quantization process

chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization/.title: Binary Number
chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization/.body:
In decimal number system, we have ten fundemental digits from 0 to 9. In binary number, we only have two numbers 0 and 1. In this section, you will learn how to convert them




  
  
    To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that
    supports HTML5 video

chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization/.title: Quantization Error
chapter1/signal-conversion-quantization/.body:
During quantization, we have to round values to the values which binary number can express, this leas errors. You need to understand how these errors come from 




  
  
    To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that
    supports HTML5 video
  



Simulation of quantization error
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
# quantization
# add to the top of the cell to enable ploting
% matplotlib inline
# generate a sin wave to simulate a continue sin signal have amplitude from -10v to +10v
t = np.linspace(0.1, 2 * np.pi, 1000)
x= 16*np.sin(t)
plt.plot(t,x);

# we are going to quantify it into a 4-bit binary signal, which can represent 16 levels
y = np.round(x)
plt.plot(t,y);

# noise 
plt.figure()
plt.plot(t,x-y);

chapter1/digital-signal-in-computer-bina.title: Digital Signal in Computer
chapter1/digital-signal-in-computer-bina.body:
We have talked a little bit about binary number but only for integer. The more common case is decimal point number. In this section, we are going to discuss two ways of representing decimal point number: Fixed point number and Floating point number.

chapter1/quiz.html.title: Quiz
chapter1/quiz.html.body:
Q1. The Nyquist theorem for sampling 

 1) Relates the conditions in time domain and frequency domain
 2) Helps in quantization
 3) Limits the bandwidth requirement
 4) Gives the spectrum of the signal

a. 1, 2 and 3 are correct
b. 1 and 2 are correct
c. 1 and 3 are correct
d. All the four are correct
Nyquist theroem specify the minimal bandwidth to sample a continue signal in time domain to a digital signal.
    





 Q2.   The interface between an analog signal and a digital processor is 

 a. D/A converter 
  b. A/D converter
 c. Modulator
 d. Demodulator
 A/D can convert analog signal to digital signal
    




 Q3. How many bit is required to code a signal with 32 levels?  
a. 8 bit
b. 4 bit
c. 2 bit
d. 1 bit
 2^8 =32 so 8 bit is required for 32 levels 
    





Q4. Which of the following is done to convert a continuous time signal into discrete time signal?
a) Modulating
b) Sampling
c) Differentiating
d) Integrating 
 sampling is a process to sample a anlog signal to a discete time signal

chapter1/assignment.html.title: Excercise
chapter1/assignment.html.body:
Question 1The number 11.5 is stored as a 32 - bit fl oating - point value in IEE754 format. Show
that the biased exponent is 130 decimal (binary 10000010) and that the fractional
part is 1.4375 decimal (binary 01110000000000000000000). Write the entire 32 - bit
representation.
Question 2In quantilization, we have following definations
The mean squire error(MSE) of quantilization error is defined as 
MSE=1N∑N(y(n)−x(n))2 
MSE=\frac{1}{N} \sum\limits_{N}{(y(n)-x(n))^{2}}
MSE=​N​​1​​​N​∑​​(y(n)−x(n))​2​​ 
The root mean square (RMS) of signal is defined as 
RMS=1N∑x2(n) 
RMS=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N} \sum{x^{2}(n) } } 
RMS=√​​N​​1​​∑x​2​​(n)​​​ 
Signal noise ration is defined as 
SNR=10log10(MSERMS2) 
SNR=10log_{10}(\frac{MSE}{RMS^{2}})
SNR=10log​10​​(​RMS​2​​​​MSE​​) 
Please calculate the SNR by quantilizing a +/- 10V sinwave with a 8-bit binary number. You can ignore the error due to the coversion between the decinal values and the binary values.
Question 3Generate a 10Hz sinwave signal and then sample it at a sampling rate 20 Hz. Then generate a 40Hz signal and then sample it at a sampling rate of 40 Hz. Compare them and then explain your observation.
